text:
As a retired police detective that worked in both Chicago and LA, I can confirm that there are many parts of this story that either don't add up or make sense. It may seem like a smaller detail when compared to some of the others, but the biggest inconstancy so far has been the timeline concerning the police/security response to the incident:

There are armed security guards and/or armed security contractors (ex military, law enforcement) working in most hotel/casinos (especially in Vegas). The security guard being shot 6 minutes prior to the attack starting would have most likely alerted the armed security detail within the resort and they would have responded. This is of course unless the security guard was unable to relay his situation via radio. However, since he was sent to investigate an alarm on the same floor, his "dispatch" would have requested status checks via radio. If he did not answer, more security would have been sent. 

It is reasonable to think once the attack started, unarmed security may have waited for police to respond. However, most armed security contractors that I have worked with would have disregarded any such order (if one was given) and would have confronted the active shooter.

^ If there is any sort of cover-up going on here, you will find the evidence in the timeline. Trust me.

Of all the ongoing conversation about the players' protests, how much of it has actually been about how to reduce the number of unjustified police shootings? 5%? 1%? Less than that? But it's not too late. If the players change their approach and take a different path to achieve their good cause, they will find we will be behind them 100%. text:
The NFL season kicked off Thursday at Sports Authority Field, home of the Denver Broncos. The stadium is just one of 36 that have received a total of $3.2 billion in tax breaks since 2000.
That's according to a new study from the Brookings Institution, which looked at 45 stadiums in the four major sports leagues that have been built or renovated in that time.
The stadiums were financed in part with municipal bonds, which are issued by local governments. Interest on those bonds is exempt from federal taxes.
Brookings calculates that the federal government lost $3.2 billion in tax revenue -- and $3.7 billion if you count the windfall that high-income bondholders get.

Dombro, new guy in town, not only underestimated the numerical contributions of David Ortiz, he failed to account for how the absence of that clutch, menacing bat in the middle of the order would affect the rest of the lineup. It wasn't just Hanley's production that fell through the floor in 2017. He then compounded the problem by trading Travis Shaw, who, almost predictably, had a breakout year offensively (.273, 31 HRs, 101RBI), for yet another injury-plagued middle reliever (Tyler Thornburg) who spent the entire 2017 season on the DL. My biggest fear is that, once other people wake up and realize what he's doing, Dombro will gut the remains of the farm system through desperate, lopsided trades before he's finally canned. This will join Red Sox folklore as the Curse of 'Lucky' Lucchino. If he had been put out to pasture years ago, I daresay Theo and Tito might still be here; Bobby Valentine (shudder!) might never have been hired; John Lester might still be near the top of their starting rotation. Each of these front-office clusters*cks (and others too numerous to name) have 'Lucky's' fingerprints all over them. If someone else wanted to share, I would help them snort up theirs.  But, nobody knew that I had my own.  It took me seven tries (so far) to kick the cocaine habit. But, that does NOT mean I will not use, tomorrow.  Get your support network established.  They don't even have to know that they are your support network.  You just need people who you can count on, to be with, when you are feeling the urge. AND, you have to get rid of those who encourage you to use, intentionally, or not.  Let me tell you, it is REALLY hard, kicking your BROTHERS loose.  And it is, almost, as difficult as explaining it to your parents.  Staying sober is EVERYTHING.  Look at what you are, sober, compared to what you are, when you are under the influence.  Which is more likely to put you in the position you want to be in, when it is time to retire? text: lol In the US soccer is a third-rate sport which very, very, very few people follow. More people play now, and that is not bad. The game can be good exercise. But in terms of fan interest and TV interest, it is all but non-existent compared to the sports which Americans in large majority numbers follow. And the fact is that most good American athletes do not take up soccer, and those who do take it up are not nearly as good as the players other countries regularly produce. There are a couple of good Americans here and there (more women than men), but they almost seem odd and fluky, and their next-door neighbors probably do not know who they are. And that is how it should be. It is not an American sport, and if Americans had genuinely found it appealing, they would have taken it up in large numbers decades ago. It is a small niche sport and is likely to remain that way, and almost no one in America will care one way or the other if the USMT makes the World Cup or not. Or even know if they do or not.
